content: Hmm not sure what’s going wrong there, but definitely make sure you’re accessing the same web3 provider throughout your app (you will of course need to have a different instance of web3.js itself on the front end). I don’t have a sample react app up yet (I promise this stuff works just fine with react — I use it for all my front ends), but here is a skeleton backend test suite with most of the items covered in the article: https://github.com/alex-miller-0/eth-dev-101 Probably my next story will be about getting a react app running alongside a node backend, but I’ve been pretty swamped lately.
